posts.cooked:
QFRCDashboard is officially ready for the 2025 season !

QFRCDashboard is an extremely lightweight, high-performance dashboard, designed to be aesthetically pleasing & easy to look at during a match, all while taking up as few driver station resources as possible.

image 1001×650 71.7 KB

image 1001×650 71.7 KB

QFRCDashboard utilizes the very high efficiency & low resource cost of the Qt framework and its QML GUI to ensure that as many resources can be allocated to the driver station app as possible. Additionally, widget & network updates are done as-needed, not constantly or periodically.

On average, QFRCDashboard uses up less than 150MB of RAM, and virtually no CPU ! By comparison, Shuffleboard uses up around 600MB of RAM, and up to 30% of the CPU on certain older systems, if not the entire CPU! Under significant load, the difference is even more pronounced, where Shuffleboard can easily climb up to 1GB or more while QFRCDashboard remains under 200MB .

In addition to basic data structures & displays, QFRCDashboard also contains several additional widgets to help display more information to the driver:

Field display with customizable robot look & vertical display

Boolean (true/false) widget with custom shapes

Enum (preset string values) widget with custom shapes & configurable colors based on a string value

QFRCDashboard contains QFRCLib, a one-file library that can interact with the dashboard in several ways:

Select tabs

Send notifications

Send alerts & errors

QFRCDashboard’s UI takes inspiration from a variety of well-known themes, including Windows 7 Aero and Windows 10 Flat, and combines it with some unique design aspects to create an aesthetic experience that complements QFRCDashboard’s excellent usability.

QFRCDashboard is designed to be dead-simple for programmers, drivers, and total strangers alike to use. Like Shuffleboard, widgets can be dragged in from a side menu, easily configured or deleted via a right-click menu, and dragged & resized via the mouse. Configuration dialogs have additionally been designed to be easy to understand & use.

QFRCDashboard will automatically open your last-opened layout file on launch, can easily and quickly open up any alternate layouts, and can even download layouts deployed to your robot!

In a future release, QFRCDashboard will additionally support pushing layouts directly to the robot, but due to WPILib limitations, this isn’t currently possible.

For guidance on installation, usage, and the many additional features present in QFRCDashboard, see its wiki !

For feedback, suggestions, bugs, or any issues or questions you may have, place them here, or on the issues tab on GitHub.

I appreciate you reading this post and showing interest in QFRCDashboard. I hope to see plenty of people use it during the season and hope to improve upon your dashboard experience!

QFRCDashboard has received dramatic changes since last season, and if you used QFRCDashboard in 2024, I encourage you to catch up by looking at the development threads since the initial 2024 release.

QFRCDashboard 2024-25 Technical Discussion

QFRCDashboard 2025 Beta - a Shuffleboard alternative Programming

Indeed, since 2024, QFRCDashboard has been completely rewritten and expanded; new features have been added, the UI was totally redesigned, and the experience was dramatically improved.

Full Changelogs:

Total UI redesign

New & improved widget configuration dialogs

Dramatically improved performance & resource usage

Removed Graph & Swerve widgets

Improved several widgets: Field2d Added shape configuration, vertical display, and red/blue alliance flipping CameraView Added quality, resolution, and framerate configuration

Field2d Added shape configuration, vertical display, and red/blue alliance flipping

Added shape configuration, vertical display, and red/blue alliance flipping

CameraView Added quality, resolution, and framerate configuration

Added quality, resolution, and framerate configuration

Fixed dozens of potential crashes

True theming support

Dramatically improved theming, & support for custom accents

Lots of UI fixes

Platform consistency

Notification support via QFRCLib

Tab-switching support

Remote layout support

Totally redesigned widget configuration UI

Totally redesigned UIs for tab management, settings, and more

Small UI inconsistencies have been fixed

UI elements now scale depending on your screen size

Dramatically reduced build time

posts.cooked: I love this so much, for teams with coprocessor programs on the laptop and potato processors this is the only dashboard they should use! great job! I will be carrying this around at events this year to help those teams out!

posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked: This is really nice, I’m glad to see other dashboards make use of remote layouts!

This release improves the UI scaling introduced in the previous release, by reducing its aggressiveness and adding an additional custom scale option for high-DPI displays.

Additionally, a status bar indicating the current connection status has been added.

Full Changelog : Comparing 2025.0.0...2025.0.1 · Q-FRC/Dashboard · GitHub

This release contains several notable QoL & aesthetic improvements alongside a critical bug fix, and updating is thus recommended for all users.

Fixed certain Windows machines being unable to save config files.

Scaling & sizing of widget configuration dialogs has been dramatically improved to fit better on small & large screens alike.

To improve platform parity, QFRCDashboard now decorates its own titlebar that looks identical on all platforms.

QFRCDashboard now supports resizing to the Driver Station window on startup.

The FMSInfo widget was redesigned to improve its compactness.

The new reef display widget takes in a boolean array and displays which sections of the reef are occupied.

Perspective is based on the driver station:

The remote layout dialog had a small bug that caused the list highlight to act erratically. This has been fixed.

Linux ARM builds are now available! WIndows ARM builds will be added in the future.

macOS builds can now run on both Intel (AMD64) and Apple Silicon (ARM64) Macs.

Full Changelog : Comparing 2025.0.1...2025.1.0 · Q-FRC/Dashboard · GitHub

link_counts.title: In Elastic or QFRCDashboard displaying reef status

posts.cooked: This release fixes a crash related to the native menu bar on MacOS.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: Hi! Is there a documentation for using this widget?
Not yet, I’ve been meaning to do so. Thanks for the reminder.

Usage of certain specialized & more complex widgets is now documented on the GitHub Wiki.

A reliable, high-performance, low-footprint dashboard for FRC use. - Q-FRC/Dashboard

Currently documented:

Spin Box/Dial

Radial Gauge (spedometer, gyro)–this will be added in 2025.2.0

Field2d

Reef Display

To be documented:

Enum

Progress Bar (upcoming)

Match Time (upcoming)

Number Display (upcoming)

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: Thanks for the info! Also, I’ve figured out that sending a boolean array of length 12 displays a reef. This widget is going to be incredibly helpful. Kudos for the amazing work!

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked:
Do I understand correctly that the Reef is display only?

Would you be able to make that something that can be interactive and retrieved using the getBooleanArray method? We were thinking this could be a good one for auto lineup on the reef.
You’re correct. I’ve been looking into ways to do this, but it’s been kind of on the back burner as I focus on my classes and some more pressing features & fixes.

I tried several different solutions for this, and this was the only one that really seemed to work.

image 944×701 26 KB

image 944×701 26 KB

image 944×701 26 KB

I’m currently looking for ways to potentially make the triangles themselves clickable.
Scratch that–I’ve devised a way to implement it directly into the triangles. This will be pushed as part of the 2025.2.0 update @2020 .

This release adds several new widgets and features.

Field2d and Dial widgets were layed out improperly.

All new widgets are documented on the wiki page .

The number display widget displays a number in large, expanding font without any editing ability.

The match time widget displays the current match time in a large, expanding font, warning the user when the timer reaches 30 seconds.

The radial gauge widget displays a number value as a gauge, useful as a spedometer or gyro.

The progress bar widget displays a number value as a percentage of a value, i.e. for robot voltage.

The reef widget is now interactive! You can now click on any of the triangles and the corresponding value will be toggled. These values can be retrieved via SmartDashboard.getBooleanArray() .

When the local and remote values don’t match for editable text and number widgets, the boxes will outline in red until the values match. The string chooser will receive this in the next update.

Full Changelog : Comparing 2025.1.1...2025.2.0 · Q-FRC/Dashboard · GitHub

This contains critical bug fixes and is recommended for all users.

Reef display widget didn’t properly update NetworkTables when clicking a triangle.

New Tab Dialog didn’t the tab name when using the OK button instead of the Enter key.

Sendable children didn’t show up in the network tree. While intentional, this behavior was adverse in the case of accessing children of Sendables, i.e. Shuffleboard tab data.

While intentional, this behavior was adverse in the case of accessing children of Sendables, i.e. Shuffleboard tab data.

String Chooser widget now displays a checkmark or x-mark depending on if the robot’s value matches the local value.

Full Changelog : Comparing 2025.2.0...2025.2.1 · Q-FRC/Dashboard · GitHub

This release contains significant performance improvements and an improved UI.

With the competition season quickly approaching, QFRCDashboard has now entered feature freeze. Bug fixes will still come as needed, but the UI and features are effectively final for the remainder of the 2025 season.

Drag & Drop and Mouse Resize had performance issues when dealing with larger tabs, often using a full CPU core during large resize operations. Now, resizing never uses up more than 0.2% of the CPU.

Reduced memory usage for certain widgets.

The title bar buttons and widget title fields overlapped with the resize anchors, making resizing the window or widgets in those areas difficult.

macOS builds would fail to run due to signing issues, Now, you still have to allow the app to run in Security & Privacy, but the app should now run on most, if not all, macOS systems without additional steps or dialogs.

The UI Theme was switched from the Universal theme to the Material theme.

Additionally, the menu bar is now integrated into the custom decoration. Note that due to implementation issues and crashes, the native macOS menu bar has been temporarily removed.

A Text Display widget has been added. This behaves identically to the number displays.

The number and text displays now have an additional color option.

You can now click on the GitHub link on the About dialog to open it in your browser.

To reduce UI clutter, spin boxes no longer have step up/down buttons.

Completely refactored the drag & drop system.

Full Changelog : Comparing 2025.2.1...2025.2.2 · Q-FRC/Dashboard · GitHub

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: For me, the dashboard keeps connecting and disconnecting from the robot. Is there any way to resolve this? Great dashboard though! Love the reef design.

I’ve only seen this happen when you mix different years of WPILib together; I remember seeing this happen when mixing a 2023 robot project with the 2024 beta QFRCDashboard or vice versa. What version of WPILib and QFRCDashboard are you using?

For the record, the latest QFRCDashboard uses 2025.1.1. There have been no changes to NT since then, and I had no issues with a 2025.3.1 project using this.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: I installed 2025.3.1 (both for the project computer) a couple of days ago, perhaps I should delete older versions.
